messageBody:
Cedric,

The failure scenario is that the superclass does something important that I
accidentally fail to invoke. Your "worker method" example below doesn't
solve this problem. I can accidentally shadow onSetUp() instead of extend it
just like I can with setUp().

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Cedric Beust
> Sent: Thursday, July 28, 2005 7:14 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] written recommendation of super.setUp/tearDown ?
>
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> > Behalf Of J. B. Rainsberger
>
> > But still, I don't know why it's a design smell to have to invoke
> > super.xxx() when you override and want to decorate a
> method's behavior.
>
> Because you need to remember to invoke super and if you
> don't, everything
> will break.
>
> Imagine a world where whenever you want to override a method,
> you need to
> look up its javadoc to know if you need to call super or not...
>
> > That's just OO.
>
> It's well established as poor OO. Real OO recommends to
> override methods to
> specialize them. If you want to provide functionality that
> should always be
> "enhanced" by subclasses and never replaced, you should
> provide template
> methods ("hooks"), as you correctly pointed out.
>
> The following code guarantees that Parent.setUp() will always
> be run, no
> matter how Parent is subclassed:
>
> public class Parent {
> private void setUp() {
> onSetUp(); // hook
> // do the thing that should always be invoked
> }
>
> public void onSetUp() {} // default is to do nothing
> }
>
> public class SubClass extends Parent {
> public void onSetUp() {
> // add my own logic to Parent.setUp()
> }
> }
>
> > As I wrote elsewhere, if super.xxx() bothers
> > you, refactor to Template Method.
>
> It's not always possible since it depends on whether the base class
> implemented the Template Method pattern or not (JUnit didn't).
